results.title: Boy of Southeast Asia
results.brief_description: Presents Geng, the young son in a typical home and his brother going to school. Shows the countryside of Southeast Asia, its ancient temples, girls fishing in rivers and river boats carrying cargo and passengers. Suitable for primary school level.
results.description: Presents Geng, the young son in a typical home and his brother going to school. Shows the countryside of Southeast Asia, its ancient temples, girls fishing in rivers and river boats carrying cargo and passengers. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Boy and a boa
results.creator_credit: Renata Stoia, Lora Hays and Boa Films
results.brief_description: The story of Martin and his pet boa is informative and entertaining. A story of a young boy and his pet boa. The boa gets loose in a library and gives the viewer a snake’s-eye view of the facilities. We are also learning a great deal about snakes and other members of the reptile family.

results.title: Boxes...boxes...boxes
results.creator_credit: Sue Wilson, Robin Dove and Coincidence Productions
results.brief_description: Shows a highschool “art event” at Hyde Park, Sydney. Includes the human sandwich, capturing space in boxes, man’s ordered existence, a 50 foot long piece of weaving, and seeing the environment from a new viewpoint.

results.title: Bowie: the video collection
results.brief_description: A wonderful collection of the innovative and ever-evolving music by British rock singer/composer, David Bowie, spanning part of his amazing career from 1972 through to 1990. Includes rare video clips and appearances by Peter Frampton, Alan Freeman, Mick Jagger and many other internationally known rock music performers. Digitally re-mastered.

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 3: Episodes 8-10.
results.creator_credit: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Life on the limit”, Extinction is forever”, and “Crackpot jackpot”. Contents include the ecological consequences of agriculture, the extinction of species, and the human role in evolution.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 2: Episodes 5-7.
results.creator_credit: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Land of opportunity”, “Latitude zero”, and “White death: new life”. Contents include the botanical uniqueness of New Zealand, the role of animals in plant reproduction, the ecological contrasts of Ecuador’s Andes, and the glacial origins of Canada’s wheatlands.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International

results.title: Botanic man. - Volume 1: Episodes 1-4.
results.creator_credit: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International
results.brief_description: A compilation of David Bellamy’s “Greenprint for life”, “The Crucible of life”, “Living Water”, and “Potential energy”. Contents include Amazon rain forest ecology, the emergence of the earliest life forms, marine ecology and the Peruvian trench, the evolutionary transition from sea to land and its legacy of peat and coal deposits.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Fleming, Graeme Duckham, Randal Beattie and Thames Television International

results.title: Boston Symphony Orchestra
results.brief_description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra in Japan in 1960, conducted by Charles Munch and Aaron Copland, includes performances of sections of major works with narration kept to a minimum. Includes complete movements or sections from the following: Easley Blackwood Jnr - “Symphony No. 1”; Hector Berlioz - “Symphony Fantastique”; Aaron Copland - “The Tender Land”; Claude Debussy - Symphonic Poem “La Mer”.

results.title: Borrowed faces
results.brief_description: Covers the audition process at the 1979 Colorado Shakespeare Festival from the viewpoints of the actors and directors. The actors’ feelings about acting, about themselves and the roles they play are examined, as well as how they handle rejections; the directors talk about how they decide which actors to cast in which roles. The final scene shows the successful actors playing the roles for which they auditioned.

results.title: Born to be small
results.creator_credit: Derek Hart, Tony Snowdon and Associated Television
results.brief_description: Looks at what it is like to be a “little person”, stressing that it is in physical size only that such people differ from others.
